fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Algebraic cellular complexes associated with a simplicial set

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given an (effective) simplicial set X, there are two major algebraic cellular complexes (or chain complexes) we can associate to it. We can consider the free abelian group generated by {\Gamma}(\Delta^n, X) at degree n, where the boundary map is given by an alternating sum of face maps: d_n = \sum_{i=0}^n (-1)^{i} \partial_i. This satisfies d^2 = 0 by the simplicial identities. ALternatively, we can consider only the geometric simplices, regarding degenerate ones are zero. More formally, we quotient out the previous chain complex by the subgroups generated by degenerate simplicies. They are both obviously effective by construction.

The first chain complex is called the non-reduced complex, while the second one is the reduced complex. By the two chain complexes are related by a chain reduction. So we will write C_* X for the reduced complex, leaving no notation for the non-reduced one unless otherwise stated.

An effective simplicial set consists of a sequence of types \operatorname{Geom}_n(X) with decidable equality, representing the geometric, a.k.a. non-degenerate, simplices. The full set of simplices, written {\Gamma}(\Delta^n, X) or more simply X_n, is given by a geometric simplex g \in \operatorname{Geom}_k(X) for some k together with a degeneracy symbol, defined as a surjection \eta : [n+1] \twoheadrightarrow [k+1], formally representing the degeneracy map that brought g up to dimension n, written as \eta^* g. The effective simplicial set is also required to have computable face maps \partial_i : \operatorname{Geom}_{n+1}(X) \to {\Gamma}(\Delta^n, X) for 0 \le i \le n+1, so that the usual simplicial identities hold. The simplicial set is of finite type if each \operatorname{Geom}_n(X) is computably finite.

Alternatively, we can make a definition that more closely follows the traditional one, requiring a sequence of types with decidable equality representing all simplices instead of geometric ones. We then need to impose an additional requirement that the degeneracy of a simplex is decidable. The equivalence of the two definitions is given by the Eilenbergâ€“Zilber lemma.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Reduction from the non-reduced chain complex to the reduced chain complex

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We construct a chain reduction from the non-reduced chain complex to the reduced chain complex in , by constructing a discrete vector field and using .

We consider placing vectors on degenerate simplicies, so that all degenerate simplices are sources or targets. For each non-trivial degeneracy symbol, if the first degeneration has even multiplicity, we assign it to be a source, with the corresponding target to have one more multiplicity at the place, and vice versa. For example, the degeneracy symbol [6] \twoheadrightarrow [4] given by the table of values (0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 4) is a source, whose target is (0, 1, 1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 4) : [7] \twoheadrightarrow [4].

To verify this indeed gives a discrete vector field, we need to show that the source is a regular face of the target. This is true since an odd consective sum of (-1)^{i} gives \pm 1. Furthermore, we need to show the admissibility of the vector field. I claim that length of the field lines originating from one cell is bounded by two times the geometric dimension (i.e. the dimension of the associated geometric simplex). On one hand, the geometric dimensions of the target and the source are the same. On the other hand, moving from the target to the next source cell requires us to pick a regular face that does not point back to the target. This is equivalent to picking a place in the degeneracy symbol with no multiplicity. Hence the geometric dimension will decrease by one.

Given an algebraic cellular complex, suppose we can encode the basis sets C_\bullet such that they have decidable equality, and the maps C_k \to \mathbb{Z}[C_{k-1}] are computable, then we say the ACC is effective. Suppose further that C_\bullet are (computably) finite sets, then we say it is effective of finite type.

An algebraic cellular complex (or ACC) is a chain complex of free abelian groups. The generators are called cells, and the boundary maps can be expressed using the generators as a basis, yielding the incidence matrices.

More precisely, we may define an ACC as a sequence of sets C_\bullet, with a sequence of functions d : C_k \to \mathbb{Z}[C_{k-1}], such that d^2 = 0 is satisfied. When a generator has non-zero coefficient in some d\sigma, the generator is called a face of \sigma.
Note that the generators of these chain groups are canonically chosen as part of the data. So a more accurate definition is a chain complex in the Kleisli category of abelian groups.
A chain complex of abelian groups is given by a sequence of abelian groups G_\bullet together with homomorphisms d_n : G_n \to G_{n-1}, such that d_{n-1} \mathbin{\circ} d_n = 0.

We construct a discrete vector field on the reduced ACC of \Delta^p \times \Delta^q whose critical cells are given by its boundary and one additional cell (0,0) < (1,0) < \cdots < (p,0) < (p,1) < \cdots < (p,q), in the representation scheme of . In particular, this gives rise to a chain reduction C_*(\Delta^p \times \Delta^q) \Rightarrow\mkern{-14mu}\Rightarrow C_*(\Delta^p) \otimes C_*(\Delta^q).

Regarding the geometric simplices as paths in a p \times q grid as specified in , we assign a (p+q)-simplex as a target cell if it contains a shape \Rsh. (The shape must go exactly one step up and one step to the right, since it is not possible otherwise in a geometric (p+q)-simplex.) To get its source cell, replace the last occurrence of this shape with \nearrow.

The sphere \mathbb{S}^n can be constructed as an effective simplicial set with exactly two geometric simplices: a zero-dimensional point, and an n-dimensional surface. All the faces of the surface are degenerate and comes from the point.
The associated reduced ACC is \mathbb{Z} at degree 0 and n and zero elsewhere. The map d is constant zero.

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Reduction from K(\mathbb{Z}, 1) to the circle

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: There is a chain reduction from the bar construction {\bar{W}}(G) of a group regarded as its reduced algebraic cellular complex, to the circle \mathbb{S}^1.

By construction, the geometric simplices of K(\mathbb{Z}, 1) are lists [a_1 \mid a_2 \mid \cdots \mid a_n] of non-zero integers. We construct an admissible discrete vector field and use the reduction it generates. We assign a cell [a_1 \mid \cdots] as a source if a_1 \ne 1. If a_1 \le 0, then we assign its target cell to be [1 \mid a_1 \mid \cdots]; otherwise we assign [1 \mid a_1 - 1 \mid \cdots]. Hence, the critical cells are [] and [1].

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: Reduction from the non-reduced chain complex to the reduced chain complex

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: We construct a chain reduction from the non-reduced chain complex to the reduced chain complex in , by constructing a discrete vector field and using .

We consider placing vectors on degenerate simplicies, so that all degenerate simplices are sources or targets. For each non-trivial degeneracy symbol, if the first degeneration has even multiplicity, we assign it to be a source, with the corresponding target to have one more multiplicity at the place, and vice versa. For example, the degeneracy symbol [6] \twoheadrightarrow [4] given by the table of values (0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 4) is a source, whose target is (0, 1, 1, 1, 2, 3, 3, 4) : [7] \twoheadrightarrow [4].

To verify this indeed gives a discrete vector field, we need to show that the source is a regular face of the target. This is true since an odd consective sum of (-1)^{i} gives \pm 1. Furthermore, we need to show the admissibility of the vector field. I claim that length of the field lines originating from one cell is bounded by two times the geometric dimension (i.e. the dimension of the associated geometric simplex). On one hand, the geometric dimensions of the target and the source are the same. On the other hand, moving from the target to the next source cell requires us to pick a regular face that does not point back to the target. This is equivalent to picking a place in the degeneracy symbol with no multiplicity. Hence the geometric dimension will decrease by one.

Given a mathematical object X canonically associated with an effective chain complex C_\bullet (X) (e.g. the normalized chain complex of a simplicial set), it is said to be equipped with the structure of effective homology, if we have a strong homology equivalence C_\bullet (X) \mathbin{\Leftarrow \mkern{-13mu} \Leftrightarrow \mkern{-13mu} \Rightarrow} E_\bullet, such that E_\bullet is effective of finite type.
